bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, July 8, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] writes that he believes Cucuta and Bucaramanga, Colombia form a permanent focus for yellow fever. He believes that both areas require mosquito control programs.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, July 8, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
July 8, 1923.
Dr. F. F. Russell,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p: Referring to your conversation of yesterday, I would add:--

1/ Spite of Porthier's assurance, I am profoundly suspicious of
the Cucuta district: (a) It does not look reasonable that this dis-
trict should have kept infected “with a fever that acclimated to the
severer yellow fever of Maracaibo” for some 10 or 15 years and then--
since about 1914--freed itself. It may be that as it confessed to a
few cases of yellow fever for only two years --1912 and 1913 as I re-
collect--it may still have this “fever of acclimatization” and not con-
sider it yellow fever.

(b) It is true that the freedom of Maracaibo from infection--for
whose condition the number of Americans present gives us a certain con-
trol--goes a good ways to exonorate Cucuta, yet the same argument would
hold (not necessarily to the same extent) that Bucaramanga was not in-
fected continuously from its great epidemic (1911-13, I think) to the
present time without infecting Cucuta. I do not, of course, know the
amount of travel from Bucaramanga to Cucuta compared to that from Cu-
cuta to Maracaibo.

(c) There is no question that the great epidemic in Bucaramanga,
to which I have alluded, was the first one--or at least the first for
many years--as a large proportion of the adult native population was af-
fected. It is quite certain that it came from Cucuta, there being none
other closertthan Guayaquil, and the rather close sequence of the out-
break at Bucaramanga upon the religious procession last fall from Cu-
cuta to Bucaramanga is--considering my last statement--at least sug-
sug-
2.
gestive.

(d) From the analogy of what we have seen elsewhere, the two dis-
tricts are more apt to form together a permanent regional focus--pos-
sibly only part of such a regional permanent focus--than either one is
to be such a focus by itself: although this too is possible.

It would seem then to the full as advisable to control Stegomyia
production in the Cucuta region as at Bucaramanga. As both should be
pretty well immunized, even a moderate reduction of Stegomyia should
be sufficient to eliminate infection.

(e) It is not improbable--although I hope it is not true--that
there are other little places in Venezuela where yellow fever may be:
being continued by going from one point to another. Naturally, it is
most apt to be found in a place commercially prosperous into which Eu-
ropeans and laborers from the high lands come. It might well, however,
be in existence in other places not frequented by Europeans, but in
such it would be little apt to be discovered.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, 2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
